etymologies: early 18th century (in the sense ‘absorption’): from modern Latin intussusceptio(n-), from Latin intus ‘within’ + susceptio(n-) (from suscipere ‘take up’)

definitions: the inversion of one portion of the intestine within another

examples.text: intussusception is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in those 3 months to 6 years of age
an intussusception may be the cause of the child's pain

shortDefinitions: inversion of one portion of intestine within another

definitions: the growth of a cell wall by the deposition of cellulose

examples.text: the area of the surface increases uniformly by intussusception

shortDefinitions: growth of cell wall by deposition of cellulose
